answers.answer: Could be a circulatory problem, where not enough blood is getting to his extremities, perhaps due to his general illnesses or juvenile diabetes or an arterial disease or a problem with his heart or lungs.  A general doc can draw blood and see what his sugars look like and he can also refer you to the specialist that would be best to diagnose this latest problem with his health.

question: My son is 12 yrs old and has been diagnosed with BCCNS (Basal-cell Carcinoma Nevus Syndrome).  He was also born with multiple birth defects; Cleft lip and pallet, hydrocephalus, craniosynostosis (Metopic), He is currently been battling Odontogenic Keratocysts and was also diagnosed with Chiaris malformation and was being monitored for a possible tethered cord.His feet go numb almost instantly when his sits down on the floor and fairly quickly when sitting in a chair, unless his legs are at a 90 degree angle.  His feet go numb along the outside of his foot and both go numb when ever he sits down.  This has been going on for 3 years now and no one can give us an idea of what could be wrong.  He recently had nerve testing done and they told us that everything was with in normal ranges.Because he has a syndrome he has multiple doctors that treat his manifestations, but none that treat his syndrome as a whole.  It is very frustrating and I am not sure where to turn to next.  He has a neurosurgeon, but not a neurologist.  We tried to get in to see one, but were refereed to a physiologist and now am not sure where to go next.
title: Numbness in both feet
